title: Correlation and Variation: Hair on Head
question_text: In a study among men of all ages, it was found that there was a correlation of $-0.8$ between how much hair you have on your head and how old you are. Which of the following is a reasonable conclusion?

choices.text: The older you are, the less hair you will have.
$80\%$ of men will lose their hair.
$80\%$ of the variation of the hair on men's heads can be explained by the variation of their ages.
$64\%$ of the variation of the hair on men's heads can be explained by the variation of their ages.
$36\%$ of the variation of the hair on men's heads can be explained by the variation of their ages.

solution:
This question combines two components: first, calculating the variation (correlation squared), and second, being able to correctly interpret it.

$$\mathrm{Variation={Correlation}^2}$$

$$\mathrm{Variation={(-0.8)}^2}$$

$$\mathrm{Variation={0.64}}$$

This leaves us with Choice 'D' as the correct answer which correctly calculates variation.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' and Choice 'B' can be eliminated, as they imply causation. Correlation does not imply causation.

Choice 'C' is the absolute value of the correlation $-0.8$ turned into a percentage.

Choice 'E' is the result of calculating the variation correctly, but then subtracting it from $100\%$.
